11:14 am
BE

Our view:
Under the existing proposal, we estimate the acquisition of RAI would be 4.7% EPS enhancing and leave the company with Net Debt/EBITDA of 3.1x. That said, assuming a 30% premium, the acquisition looks less compelling; we estimate EPS accretion of 3.8%, Net/Debt EBITDA of 3.4x and incremental ROIC post synergies of 4.1%.

BE

Key points:
Proposed acquisition of Reynolds American. Last Friday, BAT announced it intends to make an offer to acquire the 57.8% of Reynolds American it doesn't already own. Under the original offer RAI's shareholders would receive $24.13 in cash and 0.5502 BAT shares for each share in RAI, valuing each share at $56.5 (20% premium to the closing price on 20 Oct). Under these assumptions we estimate 4.7% EPS enhancement and Net Debt/EBITDA of 3.1x (Exhibit 2).

Is this the final iteration? Our view is that this is only the first step in the negotiation (at the time of the announcement BAT hadn't yet entered into negotiations with RAI). As per the FT (21 Oct) "Reynolds has informally told BAT it is open to a deal, but will need the company to increase its cash and stock offer, according to people briefed on the negotiations". At 30% premium the transaction looks less compelling. We estimate EPS accretion of 3.8%, Net Debt/EBITA of 3.4x and incremental ROIC post synergies of 4.1%. That said, we note that at European market close RAI's shares were still trading at a 2% discount to the existing proposal.

New estimates following Q3 results. BAT pre-reported 9m16 sales up 6.2% on an organic basis, continuing the strong trend registered in H1 (+6%). Organic volumes were down 1.3% in the quarter, inverting the positive trend witnessed in Q1 (+2.4%) and Q2 (+1.9%), whereas pricing at 8.1% more than compensated for the volume shortfall. Following the strong results, we now expect organic revenue growth of 5.3% for FY16 (up from 3.9% previously). This, together with updated currency estimates, translates into our new PT of £44 (up from £43).

BE

Valuation:
We believe that consumer staples stocks lend themselves to a DCF valuation methodology owing to the relative strength and predictability of their cash flow together with—in some instances—a significant mismatch between capital expenditure and depreciation charged through the profit and loss account, meaning that P&L-based valuation metrics (P/E ratio, EV/EBITDA ratio) can be misleading. We use a derivative of a traditional DCF calculation called adjusted present value, whereby the business's operating cash flows are discounted at its cost of equity (7.5%, in line with the majority of branded consumer companies) and tax shield at the cost of debt (4.0%). We use explicit forecasts out to 2018, then assume that revenue growth declines by 0.1% per annum and EBIT margin increases by 0.1% per annum. We assume a terminal growth rate of -1.0% per annum from 2025. This yields an adjusted present value of £42. Discounting this forward by one year at the cost of equity yields a 12-month price target of £44 net of our forecast dividend payment. Our price target supports our Underperform rating.

Risks to rating and price target:
Risks to our rating and price target include the following: Any improvement in the trajectory of volumes could be expected to have a positive effect on the share price. Changes in regulation of tobacco, for example, in the form of plain packaging requirements, advertising restrictions, and smoking bans, will be a significant determinant of share price performance as will decisions on the timing and extent of excise duty increases. The growth, regulation, and taxation of the e-cigarette industry, together with the part played by the existing incumbents could be significant. The trajectory of the illicit trade in cigarettes is also important.

11:19 am
BE

The proposed acquisition will make BAT a much bigger company, as adjusted net income will increase by over 30%, and one with about 45% of operating income coming from the US (previously 22% of net income came from BAT’s equity investment in Reynolds). We think it makes BAT a better company as Reynolds has the fastest-growing brands in what we regard as the most attractive major tobacco market in the world. Reynolds is gaining share because it has 42% of the market for 18-30 year old smokers, which is well above its 35% overall market share.

BE

Because of the relatively high price, however, the proposed deal looks only very modestly EPS accretive: 3% in 2018E, 6% in 2019E, once the buybacks we had assumed are removed, and the ROIC is low too. This is despite BAT going from about 2.5x ND/EBITDA in Dec ’17E to about 3.5x. This note goes through the pro-forma model in detail, and the sensitivities around all the assumptions. If the final price does indeed go higher, as we expect, then the EPS accretion is likely to be 1-2% lower. We don’t expect BAT to use amortization to reduce its US tax burden, which is what IMB did when it bought Winston in 2015.

BE

On a pro-forma basis, we continue to expect organic volume growth of about -0.5%, sales of +4%-4.5% and EBIT of +6.8%-7.5% from 2018 on (we expect slightly slower growth in 2017 due to transactional headwinds at BAT and the NPM cliff at Reynolds). RAI doesn’t dilute growth because industry volumes in the US aren’t much worse than in the rest of the world and Reynolds is gaining share, but unlike BAT elsewhere, it is benefiting materially from uptrading.

BE

Following this morning's profit warning, we cut our 2016-18E EPS by 15%/11%/11%. We reduce our multiples-based Dec-17 price target by 22% to 145p from 185p reflecting the lower earnings estimates and higher risk profile of the group. We see three key issues for investors: 1) implications for the balance sheet; 2) implications for the dividend; 3) lack of guidance on 2017 pending arrival of new management.

BE

· Details of new 2016 guidance: COB says that 2016 EBITA will be £255m-£275m, vs company-compiled consensus of c£290m. The new guidance is 6% to 12% below consensus, but 9% to 15% below the JPM estimate. On October 10, 2016, we updated our estimates for recent favourable FX moves and so we believe that the shortfall vs JPM estimates is a better reflection of the profit miss. On the conference call this morning, COB management agreed that the mid-point of its new guidance (£265m) is c£50m below the guidance it gave when it announced its rights issue on April 26, 2016. It said that 80-90% of the shortfall in profit was related to weaker revenue but we suspect that operational issues account for more than 10-20% of this new guidance.

11:26 am
BE

· 2017 outlook will probably be very unclear until March 2017: A new CEO is due to start before the end of the year and a new CFO very soon after. It makes sense for the new management team, not the outgoing team, to give 2017 guidance. COB's FY16 results are on March 2, 2017.

BE

· 2016 dividend may be at risk: When COB announced its rights issue, it said it would keep its cash dividend flat yoy in 2016, albeit the payment would be spread over a higher share count. Taking our new EPS estimates (based on the mid-point of COB's guidance today), this implies 2016E dividend cover is only 1.5x.
Balance sheet looks stretched again: COB says it will end 2016 with net debt/EBITDA of 2.6x, using average FX rates to calculate both net debt and EBITDA. Using actual year end FX rates (the accounting convention, rather than the bankers’ policy) the JPM 2016E net debt debt/EBITDA will be c2.8x. COB’s covenant (banker definition) is 3.5x.

PM

Dividend has to be a risk here

Yep. Looks like the first thing the new CEO has to do is cancel the divi that should've been cancelled by the former CEO when he called a rescue rights issue.

11:28 am
PM

It is always a signal to run

BE

Jefferiesll, since we're here. Sandy Morris.

BE

The 3Q16 trading update guides FY16 EBIT between £255m and £275m, after
favourable FX, compared with JEFe £295m and Bloomberg consensus of £290m.
We could go Route 1 where, say, a 10% downgrade results in a 20% share price
fall or we could acknowledge Cobham’s previous guidance was regarded with
some scepticism and that the risks flagged today are those also flagged at the
1H16 stage.

11:30 am
BE

Net debt and key covenant. At the 1H16 stage Cobham stated: “the Board has approved
a revised hedging policy to limit the sensitivity of its key bank covenant ratio, net debt/EBITDA,
to movements in foreign exchange rates”. Nonetheless, in 1H16 exchange movements added
£119.1m to 1H16 closing net debt of £877.2m. Expressed at 12-month rolling average
exchange rates, net debt was £786m and 12-month rolling EBITDA adjusted for acquisitions
and disposals was £345.6m, resulting in net debt/EBITDA of 2.3x for covenant purposes.
Today, Cobham estimates end FY16 net debt/EBITDA at around 2.6x. Taking the £265m
mid-point of EBIT guidance, we estimate FY16 EBITDA at around £325m, implying FY16 net
debt for covenant purposes will be similar to reported 1H16 net debt of £877m. Subject to
Cobham’s assumption about the disruption to cash flow in Mission Systems – KC-46 tanker-
related – and the effectiveness of the revised hedging policy, that might be disappointing,
but it suggests control of cash flow has not been lost.

BE

FX in 2016. In 1H16, the key average exchange rates were US$1.43/£ (1H15 = US$1.53/
£; FY15 = US$1.53/£), AUS$ 1.95/£ (1H15 = AUS$1.95/£; FY15 = AUS$2.03/£), €1.28/£
(1H15 = €1.37/£; FY15 = €1.38/£), and DKK9.54/£ (1H15 = DKK10.19/£; FY15 = DKK10.27/
£). The key foreign exchange rate spot rates are currently US$1.22/£, AUS$1.61/£, €1.125/£
and DKK8.37/£. At the 1H16 stage, Cobham noted that one cent changes in the following
exchange rates had the following translation impacts: US$ cent impacted revenue by £7m,
PBT by £1m and net debt by £6m, an AUS$ cent impacted revenue by £1m and Euro/DKK
cent impacted revenue by £3m and net debt by £1m. In broad terms, we envisaged around
a potential £18m to £20m tailwind to 2H16 EBIT versus 1H16 EBIT. Our read across from
Inmarsat and from the telecoms sector meant we had not moved to include that potential
tailwind in our forecasts.
Two more 2Q16 plus some. Cobham’s 2Q16 trading profit was £86.8m. To reach
consensus FY16 EBIT, Cobham needed 2H16 to consist of two more 2Q16 results plus around
a further £20m, some of the latter coming from cost reductions. Including FX, the reduction
in expectations for EBIT today is arguably around 15% (@£45m). We suspect that will be
seized upon and acknowledge that downgrades appear to often generate share price falls
in excess of the likely reductions to forecasts.
Give some quarter. Aside from the cautious comments about the KC-46 programme, we
believe little else has changed since the 1H16 stage. In CAES, technical issues have continued
when said to have been “substantially resolved” at the 1H16 stage. Cobham Wireless has
struggled to get back on its feet; arguably not too surprising. The read across from Inmarsat –
a 2Q16 fall in the FleetBroadband installed base – is a reminder of how tough things are in the
Marine industry. Looking to FY17, we suspect more caution will be factored into forecasts,
but Cobham’s probable 2H16 result plus some further positive FX means the reduction
to consensus EBIT expectations of £316m may not exceed 10%, in our view. All in all, our
sense is the valuation already acknowledged some risk – we recall some scepticism being
expressed about the FY16 guidance during the results presentation at the 1H16 stage – so
perhaps Cobham will be given some quarter today.

BE

Scanning the disclosures to see if they're shop. Don't think they are.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,476, down 19 (-1.27%), High: 1,505, Low: 1,476, Volume: 439.63k

BE

11:33 am
BE

"This is completely speculative. There are no negotiations underway, Burberry is not talking to Coach,' one of the sources said. Another source with first-hand knowledge of the matter said such a plan could not be on the cards since the two companies pursued very different strategies.

BE

http://uk.reuters....oach-idUKKCN12L1CB

BE

Phrasing like that makes it sound stale rather than wrong, but beyond that banal observation I have nothing to add.

11:34 am
BE

Apart, maybe, from a Jefferies note going through the rationale and deciding against.

BE

Why would this make sense for Coach? Burberry's biggest business is apparel (over 50% of sales). The acquisition would provide Coach with additional expertise in apparel, and notably outerwear, a category in which Burberry has a strong heritage and one in which Coach has recently placed emphasis. Burberry also brings experience in beauty (7% of sales, mostly fragrance), which Coach has recently begun dabbling in with the launch of fragrance this year. In addition, the deal would provide Coach with geographic diversification, as ~25% of Burberry's business is in the Americas, with the rest roughly evenly split between EMEA and AsiaPac. Burberry also brings expertise in managing multiple lines at different price points (Prorsum, London, Brit), something Coach is working to balance with its 1941 line, plus its regular Factory and full-price collections.

BE

Why would this make sense for Burberry? For Burberry, this provides further geographic diversification and a stronger foothold in the Americas. It also provides expertise in handbags, a category Burberry has been growing. In particular, Burberry has been focusing on its leather bag business (and away from canvas, nylon, and PVC), an area in which Coach has a strong heritage.

11:35 am
BE

We ran some quick math: An £18.50 purchase price would equate to a $9.2BN EV for Burberry (at curr. FX rates, excl. fees), implying 2.8x and 13.1x Mar. 2016 LTM Sales and EBITDA, respectively. Assuming a structure consistent with headlines, we modeled COH will finance 70% of the deal with stock, issue ~$2.8 billion in new debt (moving PF leverage to ~2.2x pre-synergies), and utilize $250MM of cash. Assuming rev synergies (5% of PF revs with 20% in Yr 1), COGS synergies (2% of PF COGS with 25% in Yr 1), and SG&A synergies (5% of PF SG&A with 75% in Yr 1), along with a 5% rate on new debt, we see potential accretion of $0.04 (~2%) to our existing FY'17E EPS estimate of $2.20.

BE

Our take: While this potential deal makes some strategic sense, we would still put the NT probability as relatively low. Coach has been vocal in its plans to build a platform capable of supporting multiple brands, starting with the successful acquisition of Stuart Weitzman in May 2015, and has pointed to being open to making another acquisition if the right opportunity came along. However, this deal would be a large and complicated to digest, adding significant risk at a time when Coach is making steady progress on its turnaround. We believe Coach is generally looking to acquire small to medium sized complementary brands.

BE

Further, BRBY stock has risen ~40% off its June lows while COH shares have fallen, which would make the timing inopportune for Coach from a valuation perspective, although the cheaper British Pound does help. From Burberry's standpoint, the timing might not be right. The company is currently amidst a CEO transition, with new CEO Marco Gobbetti set to start sometime next year, and lacks the team in place to integrate a major acquisition.

11:36 am
BE

That last par seems the important one. That 40% move from June lows has certainly taken much of the heat off Burberry management (as has the plan to shunt Bailey, of course).

BE

EasyJet, for some reason, getting a lot of attention on the right.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 944.00, up 25.5 (+2.78%), High: 952.00, Low: 936.82, Volume: 1.01m
11:39 am
BE

UBS pushing.

BE

One of those, "we're cutting earnings but don't expect to cut earnings after this time we cut earnings so buy on the basis that we possibly won't cut earnings again" notes.

BE

Not about the start but about the finish...despite downgrades shares attractive
On the back of three profit warnings (since the end of June) we have seen the easyJet share price nearly halve since the start of the year. However, we upgrade the shares to Buy and highlight (1) Shares are pricing in material future value destruction – we don’t think this will be the case (2) The shares have materially de-rated and we think look attractive (3) Earnings forecast risk for 2017e in our view is now balanced, and (4) Post expansion capex the FCF and ROIC look attractive.

11:40 am
BE

And although ROIC is expected to decline and FCF –ve underlying is stable
Based on our forecasts the net debt and resulting gearing ratio are expected to rise over our forecast period to 2020. Furthermore, we forecast reducing ROIC and an expected negative FCF yield to equity holders over the forecast period due to a material capex cycle. However, the company has material flexibility over its capex cycle and after capex slows we see material upside to ROIC with adjusted ROIC of over 20% in 2020e (vs c22% in 2015) and a FCF yield of c10% if expansionary capex is excluded.

BE

Although we reduce our 2017 forecasts we think a floor is being approached
Going into 2017 our main concern is around factors the company cannot control namely currency and oil movements as well as industry capacity. We downgrade our 2017e EPS by c20% (2016e increases c2% due to tax) and c10% in 2018. Market issue aside we think risk to earnings has greatly reduced in the context of the earnings downgrades seen in the previous cycle (c75% peak to trough fall) given we have already now seen over 40% downgrades in an environment which is less severe. Furthermore, easyJet has both cost and capex levers it can pull.

BE

(@BornCynic: it wasn't a complaint.)

11:41 am
BE

Valuation: PT reduced form £10.70 to £10.50 and upgrade to Buy from Neutral
Based on current forecasts easyJet's valuation appears favourable compared to the historic trading multiples. We now place easyJet on a slight recovery multiple of 7x 2017e EV/Ebitdar (previous 6.2x) which provides our new PT of £10.50 (previous £10.70). The next catalyst will be FY 2016 results on 15th November.

Market volatility picked up in September and October and a continuation of this trend through the US election would be welcome.

Plus500, a leading online trading platform provider for retail customers to trade CFDs internationally, announces that the founders of the Company, Alon Gonen1, Gal Haber2, Elad Ben-Izhak3, Omer Elazari and Shlomi Weizmann (the "Founders") have notified Plus500 that they intend to sell in aggregate up to 15,500,000 existing ordinary shares (the "Placing Shares") in the capital of the Company. 11:51 am
BE

Let me share Berenberg, who provided the charts above.

BE

Summary: Plus500 reported Q3 2016 results this morning, showing 14%
revenue growth for the first nine months of 2016 and an increase in the
EBITDA margin to 43% in Q3 from 37% at H1 2016. Growth in new and
active customers was strong at 18% and 12% respectively versus the first
nine months in 2015, though average revenue per customer growth was
more subdued, up 2%. Attention now turns to Q4. With over 82,000 new
customers added ytd, we expect the company to substantially reduce
marketing spend in Q4 and correspondingly reduce the rate of new
customer adds. Management is guiding in line with previous expectations
for FY 2016 and says that it will “focus on profitability” for the rest of the
year. As such, our forecasts remain unchanged.

PM

They are joint shop, of course

11:52 am
BE

● Customer growth: Plus500 added another 25,000 new customers in Q3
2016 to bring total new customers added during the year to just over
82,000. Active customer numbers have also been relatively steady during
the first three quarters of 2016, with nearly 70,000 customers trading in
the period. In order to hit our forecast of 89,000 new customers during
2016 (5% yoy growth), Plus500 needs to acquire only c7,000 new
customers in Q4, on our numbers.

BE

● Average revenue per customer: Average revenue per customer increased
to $1,107 in Q3 from $1,037 in Q2, a 7% improvement. This has brought the
ytd total to $1,799, up 2% yoy. The company notes that strong new
customer growth is weighing on average revenue due to customers not
contributing significant revenue in the quarter in which they sign up, but
also that there has been another slight reduction in customer churn.
● Profitability: Part of the problem with rapid new customer growth is that
the costs of acquisition and customer onboarding are felt upfront. As a
result, strong growth in net adds saw a rise in total acquisition costs for H1
which brought the EBITDA margin down to 37%, versus 44% in H1 2015.
Today’s statement notes that a 43% EBITDA margin was achieved in Q3
2016, which is an improvement, but still leaves much to do in Q4.

BE

● Focus on Q4: Assuming an average cost of acquisition of $1,300 per
customer on the 7,000 new customers noted above, this would imply that a
cost of acquisition of only c$9m is needed in Q4, much lower than the
average c$36m total cost of acquisition seen across the first three quarters
of the year. Assuming other sales and marketing costs and admin expenses
in line with prior quarters, we think a much higher margin Q4 is feasible.
● Valuation: Given the continued weakness of sterling versus the dollar,
Plus500 now trades at 7.5x 2017E P/E with a 10.7% dividend yield on the
assumption of an 80% payout ratio including special dividend. On the base
60% payout ratio, this would be an 8.0% yield.

11:57 am
BE

Has Neil Campling said anything? He's reliably good on this kind of thing.

PM

Yeah, let me share his musings

PM

The deal announced on Saturday evening is a 50/50 cash and stock deal which values Time Warner at c.$85.4B with Time Warner shareholders to receive $53.75 in cash and $53.75 in AT&T Stock (Source; AT&T Statement). The total transaction is valued at $108.7B including Time Warner’s net debt (Source: Bloomberg) to create a communication and media conglomerate.

So why would AT&T want to own Time Warner? Well we see a clear blurring of lines between content producers, aggregators and distributors in this age of internet led media/communications. TWX is an attractive asset for a number of reasons. It has the best content assets in the world in our view (HBO). It has no dual class structure unlike peers. The must see programming of Time Warner has led to higher fees extracted from distributors such as AT&T and Comcast. And it has a world class, leading eGaming business providing exposure to the most used form of media for the young generations.

11:57 am
PM

BUT content inflation seems to be at an end so why would AT&T need to own it? They don’t need to, but AT&T is under attack on two fronts. First, the success of T-Mobile US (NTCM Buy) in offering simple pricing plans has had a disruptive effect on the incumbent wireless services offerings of AT&T and Verizon. Second, the move to cord shaving and cord cutting is impacting video subscribers. Evidence of the same comes from AT&T F2Q video subscribers falling 49K (losing 391K subs at U-Verse and gaining 342K DirecTV subs) and marked the fifth quarter in a row that AT&T has lost video subs (source: company filings, Bloomberg data).

The deal is not expected to close until late 2017. The review by the DoJ and FCC will take time and is further complicated by an airwaves license for a TV station in Atlanta owned by Time Warner. The equity component of the deal is likely designed to protect the dividend of AT&T (5% DY). For AT&T post the $65.2B DTV deal closing just 15 months ago this is another significant acquisition to swallow. AT&T expects $1B in annual run rate cost synergies (primarily corporate and procurement synergies) within three years of the deal closing and net debt to adjusted EBITDA to be in the 2.5x range by the end of the first year after close.

PM

This deal sends a number of messages in our view. Holding a proverbial dumb pipe alone has little value in itself. The value is in the delivery of great content at super high speed. Which points to Comcast’s strategy of the owning of both content and an optimal delivery network has borne out. (Of course, Comcast attempted to purchase Time Warner back in 2014 but terminated the plans after pressure from the Attorney General and the FCC.) The value of media assets, where differentiated, can be used to provide strategic differentiation to sell to wireless and broadband/video customers. The result will be that the two largest distributors in the US, AT&T and Comcast, will both own major content assets. The same could pressure others such as Verizon or Charter to seek means to vertically integrate. John Malone’s Charter has already begun to battle TV networks over programming costs since a merger with Time Warner Cable arguing for lower rates for the larger combined business (as reported by the FT in September). Malone’s tentacles reach far and wide and into many forms of traditional and new age media but Verizon’s footprint doesn’t . And what of other traditional media? Perhaps the likes of Disney and Fox should look to new areas of differentiation and relevance in the face of changing consumption habits and the worrying signs in live action sports (see our thoughts in the TMT Weekly). One such ‘left field’ area would be eGaming. For example, While Disney is well positioned in the very young demographic (Mickey Mouse, Frozen etc) and older audiences (ESPN) the exposure to Generation Z and the Millenials is lacking. Electronic Arts (NTCM Buy), for example, has great exposure to sports through eGaming rather than traditional (high priced) licensed sports with FIFA, Madden, NFL etc. strong franchises. The company is also a successful gaming partner of Disney’s Star Wars franchise (a 10 year deal signed in 2015) and their PopCap games of free online content such as Bejeweled and Bookworm would appeal to the core Disney demographic in our view.

PM

In summary, there is an ongoing blurring of lines across telecom and media as the internet shapes and adapts to changing consumption habits. To us this deal shows that the telecom industry is no longer about acquiring larger numbers of telecom customers. The party has moved on. Recall that AT&T was said back in 2013 to be looking at takeovers in Europe (Source: WSJ) and KPN and EE were referenced as of potential interest at the time. So if you are left holding KPN (NTCM Sell) or Telefonica with continued expectation for market consolidation… don’t.

................ Quick line from UBS, as it's typical.

BE

We expect AT&T would enhance the pay TV bundle with Time Warner's content, not break it, similar to Comcast (Buy)/NBCU's behavior. Time Warner's strong independent culture may complicate the planned integration, and result in competitors targeting TWX marketshare. We expect TWX investors are more likely to move their holdings out of media, but feedback from our discussions with investors suggests the key media beneficiaries are likely to be CBS (Buy), FOXA (Buy), SNI (Neutral) and DIS (Buy). We believe it is likely AT&T will accelerate SVOD content being shifted from Netflix (Neutral) to its own platforms, a potential minor negative for Netflix. We break down the take- out valuation as 15x forward EBITDA for HBO, 13x for Warners, 13.5x for Turner Int'l, 11x for CNN and 8x for Turner U.S. general entertainment networks – this suggests it is the conglomerates that own Hollywood studios and premium content/networks that appear inexpensive, and limits the read-through from a cable network pure-play standpoint in our view.

BE

Telecom and cable implications
We believe AT&T is aiming to combine DirecTV and Time Warner assets to position itself to compete longer term with the cable industry, which is set to enter the market with a video-centric mobile service next year. While starting as an MVNO, we expect the cable industry to pursue the sub-scale wireless carriers – T-Mobile (Buy) and Sprint (Neutral) – to create an integrated wireless video offering and lock in existing subscribers. We do not believe the proposed deal forces Verizon (Neutral)'s hand as it continues to view linear TV as the old model. That said, suppliers of bandwidth such as tower companies and spectrum holders will likely benefit as the pieces required to create converged services are assembled sooner than expected.
